column33:
By way of Josh at OBAC/SEGA, behavior when archiving partitions fill up it typically results in a downward spiral for SOFA. It would be preferred that SOFA continue to reliability service streaming applications even if archiving fails (for any reason).

Some observed behavior/symptoms:
* High rate of logging to /var/log when archiving is failing, which causes cascade failures due to /var/log filling
* downstream streaming apps stop functioning (no further details at this point, could be 2nd or N-ary cascade failures

Marked as _low_ priority. Procedural workarounds exist to detect and recover. Ok to move to triage/backlog.

column33:
Out of the box, it looks like "gilossrv" HDF5-R Writer ({{hdf5rWriter}}) is blasting a UDP copy of every HDF5 file written. This is controlled by command line opt {{-U}}, and the {{gccommon}} seems to set this unconditionally. Looks like it might be disabled via environment {{FILEXSRV_APP_READY_PORT=0}} (e.g. in /etc/sysconfig/gilossrv). I think this or similar also applies to HDF5-H and to VCDU.

This is important because it causes additional IO load on the archive storage backend, and less importantly network and cpu load.

Keywords: FILEXSRV_APP_READY_PORT, fileTransferUDPport

Code ref:
* https://bitbucket.di2e.net/projects/SOFA/repos/sofa-hdf5/browse/src/hemi-hdf5r/ScaWriteThread.C#1218
* https://bitbucket.di2e.net/projects/SOFA/repos/sofa-admin/browse/scripts/gccommon.sh#1198

In SOFA 1.3.1, there is a new dependency (hard or soft (?)) on NORM for DSPSRV. I'm interested in refining this. If NORM is a non-optional/hard dependency, lets look for the right RPM/SPEC to encode the dependency. Even if that is a "blackbox" rpm, we can work with that by unpacking the binary rpm and editing the metadata. If it is an optional/soft dependency, then we should make sure the context is understood and in sync between the (Chef) provisioning code, and build in the right "feature flag (attribute)" in provisioning to match SOFA docs/conops.

As an aside, I'm pretty certain that NORM (Nack oriented reliable multicast) is not a feature used in TAP or OBAC/SEGA at the moment.

Also, it probably makes sense to fully on-board NORM if its a hard dep. We can develop a RPM spec and work with NRL to add them into the upstream NORM SCM. Then we can setup a TAP build, scan, package, publish pipeline to put NORM RPMs into the TAP/SEGA/SOFA baseline and repos. (But this paragraph should be a different ticket.)

*Acceptance Criteria*
 # The Application Developers' Guide is self-contained and sufficient for the app development community as verified by using it standalone to create a simple example application.

This document is described in the SOW:

4.4.8 (U) SciTec shall create a SOFA Developer's Guide for each programming language that is similar to commercial application developer guide. SciTec shall document in the SOFA Developer’s Guide the procedures to execute the SOFA build, regressing testing, packaging, and deployment processes. (Prototype Deliverable PD01)

We have determined that the second sentence describes a different document (the Custodian's Guide), and that this document should be renamed the Application Developer's Guide.

This document should have:
 * Reference to the SDK (the SDK probably has separate documentation)
 * Discussion of Datatypes, what's available, why they are useful, links to the ICDs
 * How to play back data for factory test.  (Possibly, how to use hemisim?)
 * How to use pub/sub, 0MQ, Zookeeper, etc
 * Expected data rates (how much input is the app going to be expected to ingest?  How fast is it going to be expected to produce output?)
 * Best Practices, including things like
 ** What to expect from SWAMP, Fortify, and other analysis tools that will be applied to the code
 ** Advice on how to add such tools to the developer's CI pipeline
 ** Advice on how to test
 * Delivery processes
 * What documentation will be necessary (at a minimum, a Maintainer's Guide describing how to provision the app's host system, how to install it, how to run it, etc)
 * Links to SOFA 101

*Acceptance Criteria*
 # SME analysis verifies that the LoS pointing bias from in-scene fiducials is improved relative to SOFA 3.7.2

Existing LOS QoS levels are: [HEMI HDF5-R] < [SAGE L1L] < [PoR ODP]

The goal of this Epic is to enhance HDF5-R LOS quality incrementally by (1) binging HDF5-R up to the quality of SAGE ODP processing through application of GBARS/BMOC codebases; and (2) to investigate and implement further corrections that may be required to better compare with PoR.  HDF5-R time stamps will also need to be investigated as part of the capability solution developed under this Epic.

Auto dep management in RPM is pretty good (for shared libs). Just think about any additional deps that are not explicit link-time deps... Something like {{rsync}} that you call from shell scripts won't get picked up by auto-dep discovery.
column535: Apr 06, 2020 9:37 PM;alex.griffith;[~e.hanson] can you please address James's comment? Thanks.
column536: Apr 07, 2020 5:48 PM;e.hanson;CMake generates the spec file using the CPack extension. Each project has a cmake/config_rpm.cmake ([https://bitbucket.di2e.net/projects/SOFA/repos/sofa/browse/cmake/config_RPM.cmake]) file that configures the autogenerated spec. For the most part we rely on auto deps. Stuff like rsync I don't think is being included at the moment, but we also haven't run into issues (probably because we're not testing those scripts). I don't know a good way to account for those packages other than adding them as they pop up. It'd be a pain to read through all of the scripts, most of which aren't used, and add the extra packages
column537:
Apr 07, 2020 10:48 PM;james.flemer;While it is certainly accurate that _all_ scripts in the SOFA baseline aren't actually used, I feel the ones that are used are fairly important to running in Ops. I'm mostly thinking of scripts related to file transfer and file clean-up, and possibly the scripts related to (distributed) playback setup. I guess we'll find out if there are any hidden deps in those, in ops. ;-)

And please remember that Ops installs start with pretty bare bones set of base RPMs, likely far less than in factory or DI2E environments, and possibly less than TAP.

But maybe you could add in {{BuildRequires}} (like HEMI spec files) as it is very helpful when building in a air-gap where access to DI2E jenkins isn't an option. The CPack RPM extension supports {{BuildRequires}} via {{CPACK_RPM_BUILDREQUIRES}}, but isn't used in the cmake file linked above. Those should be easily found in the legacy spec files. It's probably rare to build outside CI/CD ... so pile this on the backlog for "later".

column33:
According to the GAI team, there was a feature added in HEMI 3.8.x.

GAI is producing a new VCID (VCID-53) which needs to be muxed back into the wideband feed. There was a feature implemented in rdsrv to support this.

My quick take on it was that rdsrv orginally was 1:N data forwarding. Only source socket equals one data feed. This new feature was to allow two source sockets to be output on the same feed (i.e. muxing).

This feature is for OBAC.

column33:
This as an enhancement to the current implementation of the GBARS attitude lock indicator. Right now, the TAP lab isn't even using SOFA gbars, so this should not be addressed until we address the SOFA gbars issues.

The attitude lock indicator criteria needs to be reevaluated to accurately report when the GBARS LOS is locked, degraded, or poor. It appears the GEO lock indicator has been drastically loosened because the LOS "goes green" (reports locked status) after just a couple stars when POR (program of record aka SBIRS) can take over an hour to lock.
column251:
Additional info from Rho:

"{color:#000000}I added this as an enhancement to the GBARS attitude lock indicator. Right now we aren't even using SOFA gbars, so it's really a mute point. But when/if we have time to address the SOFA gbars issues, we should reevaluate when the GBARS LOS is high, medium and low quality. Right now the status is based off of about 12 different conditions ranging from number of starts received and the past x time, percentage of stars rejected. covariance, and a bunch of other stuff I've forgotten. However, it seems that the GEO conditions have been modified because it reports locked LOS after just a couple stars (when in reality it should take about an hour to converge).{color}

In LoadVCduThread.C

the port number is set to 0.

This causes the bind call in Zserver.C
https://bitbucket.di2e.net/projects/SOFA/repos/common-core/browse/src/common-core/Zserver.C#489
to connect using an ephemeral port.

The issue is that the port needs to be predetermined.

cd <docker dir>
